skills_only_or_tool_training.rationale: The course covers empirical research methods but applies them to substantive questions about international organizations. It is not solely focused on skills or tool training but rather on applying methods to theoretical and analytical questions.

lacks_major_deliverable.rationale: The draft research paper and its associated progress assignments constitute a major intellectual deliverable representing 30% of the course grade.

already_counted.rationale: There is no indication in the syllabus that this course is already counted through another Honors credit mechanism.

review_decision.rationale: The course meets two pillars (undergraduate research and leadership development), satisfies all three rigor criteria (advanced content, sustained inquiry, and independent work), meets all three student agency criteria (student-defined projects, consequential decision-making, and extended analytical commitment), and demonstrates clear evidence of learning through a major project and sustained assessment structure. No exclusions apply. The course clearly meets Honors teaching and learning expectations through its emphasis on original empirical research, critical engagement with scholarly literature, and sustained intellectual work.

interdisciplinary_academics.rationale: The course integrates perspectives from law, political science, and conflict studies. The syllabus explicitly states students will use 'qualitative and/or quantitative analysis' and explores law through 'conceptual lenses like economics, sociology, or anthropology,' demonstrating intentional integration of multiple disciplinary perspectives necessary to the learning outcomes.

undergraduate_research.rationale: Students engage in original inquiry through written assignments requiring them to formulate questions, review literature, advance arguments, and propose implications. The presentation assignment requires students to 'note a question in an engaging and compelling way, succinctly and coherently review existing literature or facts... advance an argument or explanation,' extending beyond established answers.

community_and_global_engagement.rationale: The course connects academic learning to real-world global conflicts through sustained engagement with current events, case studies of actual conflicts, and requires students to 'pick a conflict to work on throughout the semester.' Weekly discussions begin with 'current event involving the week's topic,' and assignments include engagement with policy briefs, news sources, and real-world case analysis.

leadership_development.rationale: The syllabus does not provide evidence of intentional development of leadership capacity through decision-making, responsibility, or influence in academic, professional, or civic contexts. While students analyze legal frameworks and ethical dimensions of conflict, there is no structured practice or reflection on leadership or ethical frameworks as applied to personal development.

advanced_content.rationale: The course is described as an 'advanced seminar' covering advanced theoretical and methodological content. The syllabus notes 'some of the materials presented may be technically or theoretically challenging' and includes 'advanced statistics,' and focuses on recent scholarly work requiring sophisticated conceptual analysis of law, legal pluralism, and conflict.

sustained_inquiry.rationale: Students engage in sustained inquiry across the term by selecting one conflict to focus on throughout the semester for written assignments and presentations. The course structure requires ongoing analysis across 16 weeks, with multiple written assignments building toward a final presentation.

independent_or_collaborative_work.rationale: The course requires significant independent intellectual work through written assignments constituting 40% of grade, presentations at 40%, and weekly reading and discussion preparation. Students must independently formulate research questions, conduct literature reviews, and develop original arguments.

student_defined_projects.rationale: Students select their own conflict to analyze throughout the semester and choose the format of their assignments (case brief, policy brief, or mini research design) 'depending on your career goals.' The presentation topic is also student-selected, demonstrating significant student agency in shaping their work.

consequential_decision_making.rationale: Students make consequential decisions about which conflict to study, what format to use for assignments, and what arguments to advance. These decisions have intellectual consequences as they shape the questions asked, evidence used, and implications proposed, as emphasized in course objective 7.

extended_analytical_commitment.rationale: The work requires extended analytical commitment as students develop their understanding of a single conflict throughout the semester, building through multiple written assignments (40% of grade) and culminating in a presentation (40%). Students receive feedback through Brightspace discussions and meet with instructor to review outlines.

major_project.rationale: The presentation constitutes 40% of the course grade and requires students to formulate a question, review literature/facts, advance an argument, and propose implications. Written assignments also constitute 40% of grade. Together these major deliverables represent 80% of the final grade.

portfolio_or_capstone.rationale: While students work on one conflict throughout the semester, there is no evidence of a portfolio or capstone-style artifact that explicitly integrates and reflects on work across the term.

public_facing_outcome.rationale: Students deliver 5-minute presentations in Week 16 that require academic judgment and are presented to the class. The presentation format options (case brief, policy brief, research design) suggest application to real-world contexts and audiences beyond the classroom.

sustained_assessment.rationale: The majority of graded work requires critical analysis and synthesis: written assignments through Brightspace discussions (40%), presentation requiring argument development and literature review (40%), and participation requiring critical engagement with readings (20%). All assessments demand analytical engagement rather than recall.

lower_division_introductory.rationale: The course is described as an 'advanced seminar' (POL 435 is a 400-level course) and explicitly states it focuses on recent scholarly work rather than introductory content. It builds on foundational knowledge rather than introducing basic concepts.

broad_introductory_coverage.rationale: The course is focused on advanced analysis of the relationship between law and conflict, not broad introductory coverage. The syllabus notes the focus is intentional to 'provide analytical focus' rather than comprehensive coverage.

skills_only_or_tool_training.rationale: The course is not skills-only or tool training. It requires theoretical engagement, critical analysis, and original argumentation about complex questions regarding law and conflict.

lacks_major_deliverable.rationale: The course has major intellectual deliverables: written assignments (40%) and presentation (40%) that require formulating questions, reviewing literature, advancing arguments, and proposing implications.

already_counted.rationale: No evidence in the syllabus suggests this course is already counted through another Honors credit mechanism.

review_decision.rationale: This course meets the criteria for Honors credit. It demonstrates three pillars: interdisciplinary academics (integrating law, political science, and conflict studies), undergraduate research (original inquiry and question formulation), and community and global engagement (sustained engagement with real-world conflicts). It satisfies all rigor criteria through advanced content, sustained inquiry, and independent work. Student agency is demonstrated through student-defined projects, consequential decision-making, and extended analytical commitment. Evidence of learning is shown through major projects (80% of grade), public-facing presentations, and sustained assessment requiring critical analysis. No exclusions apply.

interdisciplinary_academics.rationale: The course is listed as a core requirement for Purdue's undergraduate Human Rights Minor and integrates 'interrelated legal and philosophical concepts' alongside political science perspectives (Objective 1), drawing from law, philosophy, and political science to understand human rights theory and practice.

undergraduate_research.rationale: The course requires students to 'Evaluate causes of and solutions for international human rights violations' (Objective 3) through multiple papers (Paper 1 and Paper 2, each worth 20%) and a Causal Theory Exam (20%), indicating sustained analytical inquiry and original evaluation beyond established answers.

community_and_global_engagement.rationale: The course explicitly focuses on 'historical and ongoing situations of human rights violations' (Objective 2) and addresses 'why violations occur, and prevention of human rights violations' globally, connecting academic learning to real-world international human rights contexts throughout the curriculum.

leadership_development.rationale: The Torture Debate Position Paper (10%) requires students to take an ethical stance and defend a position on a consequential human rights issue, developing capacity for decision-making and analysis of ethical frameworks in human rights contexts.

advanced_content.rationale: The course engages advanced theoretical content through in-depth study of philosophical texts (Arendt's Eichmann in Jerusalem), legal frameworks (human rights treaties), and psychological theories (Staub's work), as evidenced by the Causal Theory Exam and multiple analytical papers.

sustained_inquiry.rationale: The course requires sustained inquiry across the term through a Causal Theory Exam (20%), two major papers (20% each), position paper, and two quizzes, all requiring ongoing analytical engagement with human rights concepts and cases.

independent_or_collaborative_work.rationale: Students must complete significant independent work including two major papers (40% combined), a position paper (10%), and a causal theory exam (20%), all requiring substantial independent intellectual effort.

student_defined_projects.rationale: The syllabus does not provide evidence that students define their own project topics or research questions; assignments appear to be instructor-defined.

consequential_decision_making.rationale: The Torture Debate Position Paper requires students to take and defend an ethical position on torture, representing consequential decision-making on a fundamental human rights issue with moral and intellectual weight.

extended_analytical_commitment.rationale: The two major papers (20% each) and Causal Theory Exam (20%) require extended analytical commitment to human rights theory, historical cases, and causal analysis across the semester.

major_project.rationale: The course includes two major papers, each constituting 20% of the final grade, representing significant intellectual deliverables that demonstrate advanced learning.

portfolio_or_capstone.rationale: The syllabus does not describe a portfolio or capstone-style artifact integrating work across the term.

public_facing_outcome.rationale: There is no evidence in the syllabus of public-facing or applied outcomes such as presentations, community projects, or public scholarship.

sustained_assessment.rationale: The majority of graded work (80%) consists of papers, exams, and position papers requiring critical analysis, synthesis, and original contribution to understanding human rights issues, violations, and solutions.

lower_division_introductory.rationale: POL 43801 is a 400-level course, indicating upper-division status, not a lower-division introductory course.

broad_introductory_coverage.rationale: The course focuses on advanced analysis of human rights violations, causal theories, and philosophical frameworks rather than broad introductory coverage.

skills_only_or_tool_training.rationale: The course is focused on analysis, evaluation, and comprehension of human rights concepts and cases, not skills-only or tool training.

lacks_major_deliverable.rationale: The course includes two major papers (20% each) and a causal theory exam (20%), constituting substantial intellectual deliverables.

already_counted.rationale: There is no evidence in the syllabus that this course is already counted through another Honors credit mechanism.

review_decision.rationale: The course meets all four pillars (interdisciplinary academics, undergraduate research, community and global engagement, and leadership development), satisfies all rigor criteria (advanced content, sustained inquiry, and independent work), meets student agency requirements (consequential decision-making and extended analytical commitment), demonstrates evidence of learning through major papers and sustained assessment, and triggers no exclusions.

interdisciplinary_academics.rationale: The course remains within the discipline of political science, drawing on theories, frameworks, and case studies from within that field. There is no evidence of intentional integration of perspectives from other distinct disciplines (e.g., economics, engineering, natural sciences) that are necessary to the learning outcomes.

undergraduate_research.rationale: While students analyze case studies and apply decision-making frameworks, the syllabus does not indicate that students formulate original research questions, conduct independent investigations, or produce original findings that extend beyond established knowledge in the field.

community_and_global_engagement.rationale: The course examines U.S. foreign policy and global relationships, but there is no evidence of sustained engagement with external communities, organizations, or structured reflection on the ethical, social, or cultural dimensions of such engagement. The war game simulation is classroom-based, not community-engaged.

leadership_development.rationale: The war game simulation requires students to 'work together to solve a pressing foreign policy issue,' involving decision-making with ethical and strategic consequences. The two-page reflection requires students to 'provide personal feedback and reflect on the outcome,' demonstrating intentional practice and reflection on decision-making processes central to leadership development.

advanced_content.rationale: The course engages with advanced theoretical frameworks for foreign policy decision-making, including unitary state, cognitive, organizational process, and bureaucratic politics perspectives, and applies these to complex case studies such as the Iran nuclear standoff and Bin Laden assassination.

sustained_inquiry.rationale: Students engage in sustained inquiry through the three-part war game simulation that spans multiple weeks (Weeks 12-14), requiring application of course material to a pressing foreign policy problem, culminating in a written reflection.

independent_or_collaborative_work.rationale: The war game simulation explicitly involves collaborative intellectual work as 'the class will work together to solve a pressing foreign policy issue.' The framework writing assignments and final exam also require significant independent analytical work applying course frameworks.

student_defined_projects.rationale: All assignments, including the war game simulation and framework writing assignments, appear to be instructor-defined. There is no evidence that students define or shape their own research questions or project topics.

consequential_decision_making.rationale: The war game simulation involves students making decisions about 'a pressing foreign policy issue' with strategic and ethical implications. The reflection component indicates students must consider the 'outcome' of their decisions, suggesting intellectual consequences.

extended_analytical_commitment.rationale: The final exam involves extended analytical commitment, as students must prepare for 3-5 essay questions distributed in advance and respond to essay questions requiring synthesis of course material. The framework writing assignments also require sustained application of decision-making frameworks to course content.

major_project.rationale: The war game simulation with write-up (15% of grade) and the final exam (20% of grade) each constitute major intellectual deliverables. Together, these represent 35% of the course grade and require substantial analytical work.

portfolio_or_capstone.rationale: There is no portfolio or capstone-style artifact that integrates work across the term. Assignments are discrete rather than cumulative in a portfolio format.

public_facing_outcome.rationale: The war game simulation and written assignments are classroom-based and do not appear to have public-facing or applied outcomes beyond the academic context.

sustained_assessment.rationale: The course includes sustained assessment through framework writing assignments (10%), two module exams (30%), war game simulation and write-up (15%), and a final exam (20%). Together, 75% of the grade requires critical analysis and application of decision-making frameworks to foreign policy scenarios.

lower_division_introductory.rationale: The course 'builds on the foundations of U.S. foreign policy' and engages with advanced theoretical frameworks and case applications, suggesting it is not a lower-division introductory course.

broad_introductory_coverage.rationale: While the course provides a 'comprehensive overview,' it moves beyond broad coverage to focused application of decision-making frameworks through case studies and simulation, requiring advanced analysis rather than survey-level introduction.

skills_only_or_tool_training.rationale: The course is not focused on skills or tool training; it emphasizes theoretical frameworks, analytical application, and critical decision-making in foreign policy contexts.

lacks_major_deliverable.rationale: The course includes multiple major deliverables: the war game simulation with write-up (15%), framework writing assignments (10%), module exams (30%), and final exam (20%).

already_counted.rationale: There is no indication that this course is already counted through another Honors credit mechanism.

review_decision.rationale: The course meets the leadership development pillar through its war game simulation requiring consequential decision-making and reflection. It satisfies all three rigor criteria (advanced content in decision-making frameworks, sustained inquiry through the multi-week simulation, and collaborative work). It meets student agency requirements through consequential decision-making and extended analytical commitment. It demonstrates learning through major projects (simulation and final exam) and sustained assessment. No exclusions apply.

course_information.course_title: Game Theory & Strategy in Political Science

interdisciplinary_academics.rationale: The course explicitly integrates game theory (a mathematical/analytical method) with political science applications. The course description states it will 'apply these basic game theoretic tools to important problems in political science' and outcomes include applying 'game theoretic concepts to explain actions and outcomes in important contemporary and historical cases in political science, policy, and politics.'

undergraduate_research.rationale: The final project requires students to either 'select a real world event or situation, represent it using a game theoretic model, and discuss implications' or 'propose a research design that makes use of behavioral game theory,' both of which involve original inquiry and knowledge creation beyond established answers.

community_and_global_engagement.rationale: The syllabus does not mention sustained engagement with communities, organizations, or global issues, nor does it include structured reflection on ethical, social, or cultural dimensions of such engagement.

leadership_development.rationale: The syllabus does not include intentional development of leadership capacity, decision-making responsibility, or analysis of leadership frameworks. The course focuses on analytical problem-solving within game theory.

advanced_content.rationale: The course covers advanced theoretical concepts including 'strategic rationality, best responses, normal and strategic form games, backward induction, and games of incomplete information,' which represent advanced analytical and methodological content in game theory.

sustained_inquiry.rationale: The final project (15% of grade) requires sustained inquiry as students must select real-world events, model them using game theory, and discuss implications, or develop a research design—work that extends across the term.

independent_or_collaborative_work.rationale: The final project requires significant independent intellectual work involving selection of cases, application of game theoretic modeling, and analysis of implications or research design development.

student_defined_projects.rationale: The final project explicitly allows students to 'select a real world event or situation' and choose between two different project types (modeling approach or research design), demonstrating student-shaped projects and questions.

consequential_decision_making.rationale: Students must make consequential intellectual decisions in the final project, including which real-world situation to model, how to represent it game theoretically, and what implications to draw—choices that affect the quality and validity of their analysis.

extended_analytical_commitment.rationale: The final project requires extended analytical commitment as students must model real-world situations using game theory and discuss implications, requiring sustained application of course concepts and iterative development of their analysis.

major_project.rationale: The final project (15% of grade) constitutes a significant deliverable requiring students to apply game theoretic modeling to real-world situations or develop a research design, demonstrating integration of course concepts.

portfolio_or_capstone.rationale: The syllabus does not describe a portfolio or capstone-style artifact that integrates work across the term; the final project is a standalone assignment.

public_facing_outcome.rationale: The final project does not appear to have a public-facing component; it is submitted for grading without mention of public presentation or applied outcomes requiring external judgment.

sustained_assessment.rationale: The course includes sustained assessment through weekly quizzes (30%), in-class assignments and participation (15%), a midterm exam (30%), and a final project (15%), with the majority requiring application and analysis of game theoretic concepts rather than mere recall.

lower_division_introductory.rationale: POL 450 is a 400-level course, indicating upper-division status, and the content involves advanced game theoretic concepts rather than foundational introductions.

broad_introductory_coverage.rationale: While the course 'introduces students to the basics of game theory,' it is a 400-level course focused on advanced analysis and application rather than broad coverage, as evidenced by the requirement to 'derive equilibria' and apply concepts to specific political science problems.

skills_only_or_tool_training.rationale: The course goes beyond skills training by requiring students to apply game theory to explain political phenomena and develop original analyses through the final project.

lacks_major_deliverable.rationale: The course includes a final project (15%) requiring original application of game theory to real-world situations or research design development, constituting a major intellectual deliverable.

already_counted.rationale: No evidence in the syllabus suggests this course is already counted through another Honors credit mechanism.

review_decision.rationale: The course meets two pillars (interdisciplinary academics and undergraduate research), satisfies all three rigor criteria (advanced content, sustained inquiry, and independent work), meets all three student agency criteria (student-defined projects, consequential decision-making, and extended analytical commitment), and demonstrates learning through both a major project and sustained assessment. No exclusions apply.

interdisciplinary_academics.rationale: The course focuses exclusively on American judicial politics within the political science discipline. While it examines social, economic, and political pressures on courts, it does not integrate distinct disciplinary perspectives or methods from fields outside political science in ways necessary to the learning outcomes.

undergraduate_research.rationale: The course includes a 'short creative paper' on judicial review, but the syllabus provides no evidence that students engage in inquiry extending beyond established answers, formulate original research questions, or produce original findings. The paper appears to be an analytical exercise rather than research producing new knowledge.

community_and_global_engagement.rationale: The syllabus contains no references to community partnerships, engagement with organizations, real-world contexts beyond classroom case analysis, or structured reflection on ethical, social, or cultural dimensions of engagement with external communities.

leadership_development.rationale: The course does not include intentional practice in decision-making, taking responsibility, or influencing outcomes. While students analyze judicial power and decision-making, there is no evidence of developing students' own capacity for leadership through reflection or analysis of leadership frameworks.

advanced_content.rationale: The course is upper-level (46000) with prerequisite American Government knowledge, examines advanced theoretical frameworks (attitudinal model, judicial supremacy, constitutional authority), and analyzes complex Supreme Court cases and their political contexts through sophisticated scholarly readings.

sustained_inquiry.rationale: The course involves sustained inquiry across the 16-week term, progressing from institutional foundations through agenda-setting, decision-making, judicial review across multiple domains (rights, equality), and institutional competition, culminating in analysis of judicial dialogue and constitutional authority.

independent_or_collaborative_work.rationale: Students must complete a judicial review paper independently (10% of grade), engage with complex readings throughout the term, and demonstrate synthesis of material on exams (70% combined). The work requires significant independent intellectual engagement with course material.

student_defined_projects.rationale: The syllabus describes a 'short creative paper' on judicial review due November 18, but provides no evidence that students define their own questions, shape project parameters, or have choice in topic selection. The assignment appears pre-structured by the instructor.

consequential_decision_making.rationale: While students analyze judicial decision-making in the course content, there is no evidence that students themselves engage in decision-making with intellectual or ethical consequences. Participation is attendance-based (iClicker) rather than involving consequential choices.

extended_analytical_commitment.rationale: The course requires extended analytical commitment through sustained engagement with complex theoretical frameworks across 16 weeks, synthesizing material for two major examinations (70% of grade) and a paper, demonstrating iterative development of understanding of judicial politics.

major_project.rationale: The judicial review paper constitutes only 10% of the course grade and is described as 'short,' which does not meet the threshold for a major paper, project, or deliverable constituting a significant portion of the grade.

portfolio_or_capstone.rationale: The syllabus contains no evidence of a portfolio or capstone-style artifact that integrates work across the term. Assessment consists of discrete exams, a paper, and participation rather than cumulative integration.

public_facing_outcome.rationale: All course deliverables (exams, paper) are submitted to the instructor via Brightspace or in-class. There is no evidence of public-facing or applied outcomes requiring academic judgment presented to audiences beyond the instructor.

sustained_assessment.rationale: The majority of graded work (80%: two exams at 30% and 40%, plus a 10% paper) requires critical analysis and synthesis of complex judicial politics concepts, theoretical frameworks, and Supreme Court cases, demonstrating sustained analytical assessment throughout the term.

lower_division_introductory.rationale: This is an upper-level (46000) undergraduate course with prerequisites (POL 10100 or POLS Y1030), not a lower-division introductory course. It builds on foundational knowledge of American government.

broad_introductory_coverage.rationale: While the course covers multiple aspects of judicial politics (trial courts, appellate courts, Supreme Court), it focuses on advanced analysis of judicial power, decision-making models, and institutional competition rather than broad introductory coverage. The readings include specialized scholarly works.

skills_only_or_tool_training.rationale: The course is substantive and analytical, examining judicial politics through theoretical frameworks and case analysis. While it develops analytical skills including 'quantitative assessment of the judiciary,' this is embedded in broader conceptual learning, not pure tool training.

lacks_major_deliverable.rationale: The course includes major deliverables: a midterm exam (30%), final exam (40%), and a judicial review paper (10%). The exams constitute substantial intellectual work requiring synthesis and analysis of course material.

already_counted.rationale: There is no indication in the syllabus that this course is already counted through another Honors credit mechanism.

review_decision.rationale: While the course meets rigor requirements (advanced content, sustained inquiry, independent work) and demonstrates sustained assessment of learning, it does not meet any of the four Honors College pillars. The course is a traditional upper-level political science course examining judicial politics without interdisciplinary integration, undergraduate research, community engagement, or leadership development. Without meeting at least one pillar, the course cannot be approved for Honors credit.

interdisciplinary_academics.rationale: The course is cross-listed as POL 222/WGSS 281, integrating Political Science (Social Sciences domain) with Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies (Humanities domain). The course description demonstrates integration by examining 'the ways in which gender intersects with race and class to influence politics and public policy,' combining political science frameworks with gender studies perspectives on structural oppression and intersectionality.

undergraduate_research.rationale: The syllabus does not describe any inquiry, investigation, or knowledge creation extending beyond established answers. Assessments consist of discussion posts, quizzes, and exams that test understanding of existing course materials rather than engaging students in formulating original research questions or producing novel findings.

community_and_global_engagement.rationale: While the course addresses real-world political and social issues affecting women, there is no evidence of sustained engagement with communities, organizations, or structured reflection on ethical, social, or cultural dimensions of external engagement. The course is asynchronous online with no community-based learning components.

leadership_development.rationale: The syllabus does not include intentional practice in decision-making, taking responsibility, or influencing outcomes in academic, professional, or civic contexts. There is no evidence of reflection on leadership or ethical frameworks through structured activities or assignments.

advanced_content.rationale: The course includes advanced theoretical content, examining intersectionality theory, feminist political theory, and structural analysis of gender, race, and class. Learning outcomes require students to 'analyze the challenges in designing and implementing effective policy solutions to gender-related problems,' demonstrating analytical depth beyond introductory coverage.

sustained_inquiry.rationale: The course does not involve sustained inquiry, design, or problem-solving across the term. Assessments are primarily consumption-based (reading, watching videos) followed by quizzes and exams testing comprehension rather than iterative investigation or extended analysis.

independent_or_collaborative_work.rationale: While the course requires weekly discussion posts, these are brief (a few sentences to a paragraph) and do not constitute significant independent or collaborative intellectual work. There are no major papers, projects, or sustained analytical assignments requiring extended independent effort.

student_defined_projects.rationale: The syllabus provides no evidence of student-defined or student-shaped projects or questions. All assignments appear to be instructor-defined with predetermined prompts and formats.

consequential_decision_making.rationale: The course does not involve decision-making with intellectual or ethical consequences. Assessments focus on demonstrating comprehension of course materials rather than making consequential choices about inquiry, analysis, or application.

extended_analytical_commitment.rationale: The course does not require extended analytical commitment or iterative review/response. Discussion posts are brief weekly exercises, and exams are multiple-choice assessments that do not involve iterative development or sustained analytical engagement.

major_project.rationale: The course does not include a major paper, project, design, or performance. The final exam, while weighted at 26% of the grade, is a multiple-choice cumulative assessment rather than a major intellectual deliverable requiring synthesis or original contribution.

portfolio_or_capstone.rationale: There is no portfolio or capstone-style artifact integrating work across the term. Assessments are discrete quizzes, exams, and discussion posts rather than cumulative integrative work.

public_facing_outcome.rationale: The course does not include a public-facing or applied outcome requiring academic judgment. All work is submitted privately via Brightspace for instructor/TA evaluation.

sustained_assessment.rationale: The majority of graded work consists of multiple-choice quizzes and exams (71% of grade) rather than critical analysis, synthesis, or original contribution. Discussion posts (14% of grade) are brief and focused on demonstrating understanding rather than sustained analytical work.

lower_division_introductory.rationale: POL 222 is a 200-level course designed to introduce women's participation in politics. The catalog description states it is 'an introduction to women's participation in politics' and WGSS 281 'examines in depth particular topics from the introductory course in Women's Studies,' indicating this builds on foundational content but is itself positioned as lower-division coverage.

broad_introductory_coverage.rationale: The course provides 'an overview of women as political actors: citizens, activists, candidates, and officeholders' and covers history, contemporary activities, and various policy domains. The breadth of topics and assessment structure (quizzes and multiple-choice exams) suggest coverage-oriented rather than advanced analytical focus.

skills_only_or_tool_training.rationale: The course is not focused solely on skills or tool training. It addresses substantive content on gender, politics, and public policy through conceptual and theoretical frameworks.

lacks_major_deliverable.rationale: The course lacks a major intellectual deliverable. Assessments consist primarily of multiple-choice quizzes and exams and brief discussion posts. There is no major paper, project, or sustained analytical work requiring synthesis or original contribution.

already_counted.rationale: There is no indication the course is already counted through another Honors credit mechanism.

review_decision.rationale: The course is not approved because it meets one pillar (interdisciplinary_academics) but triggers three exclusions: it is a lower-division introductory course (POL 222 at 200-level), focused on broad introductory coverage of women in politics, and lacks a major intellectual deliverable. Additionally, the course does not meet the student agency and responsibility criteria (all scored 0) and does not provide demonstrable evidence of learning through major projects or sustained assessment. The assessment structure relies primarily on multiple-choice quizzes and exams testing comprehension rather than advancing critical analysis or original contribution expected of Honors courses.

interdisciplinary_academics.rationale: The course explicitly integrates political science (Social Sciences domain) with political ecology (which draws from both Natural Sciences and Social Sciences), combining theoretical frameworks from both disciplines. The course description states it provides 'an introduction to environmental politics and policy from the perspectives of political science and political ecology,' and examines 'theoretical, methodological, and practical approaches' from both mainstream and critical perspectives, indicating genuine cross-domain integration in addressing environmental problems.

undergraduate_research.rationale: Students conduct an Environmental Policy Research Project that involves formulating research questions (research proposal), collecting and analyzing evidence (annotated bibliography), and producing original findings (policy brief). The project description states students will 'conduct a policy research project on a problem or issue for environmental politics' that includes identifying a relevant problem, describing its importance, and outlining a research strategy, demonstrating engagement in inquiry and knowledge creation beyond established answers.

community_and_global_engagement.rationale: While the course addresses environmental justice and global issues conceptually, there is no evidence of sustained engagement with actual communities, organizations, or structured reflection on ethical/social dimensions through direct engagement. The policy brief is described as addressing 'a policy-relevant audience' but does not require interaction with real-world communities or organizations.

leadership_development.rationale: The course does not include explicit components for developing leadership capacity through intentional practice, reflection on leadership frameworks, or opportunities for students to make decisions, take responsibility, or influence outcomes in academic, professional, or civic contexts. While students make analytical decisions in their research, this does not constitute leadership development as defined.

advanced_content.rationale: The course covers advanced theoretical content including mainstream and critical approaches to environmental politics and policy, political ecology frameworks, and complex issues like climate change, environmental justice, and natural resource management. Learning outcomes require students to 'critique different views on several crucial debates' and 'apply different approaches to analyzing and solving public policy problems,' indicating analysis beyond introductory level.

sustained_inquiry.rationale: The Environmental Policy Research Project represents sustained inquiry across the term, beginning with a research proposal, progressing through an annotated bibliography, draft submission, peer review, and culminating in a final policy brief. This multi-stage process conducted 'throughout the course of the semester' demonstrates sustained intellectual engagement with a problem.

independent_or_collaborative_work.rationale: The Environmental Policy Research Project requires significant independent intellectual work, including formulating research questions, conducting literature review, and producing an original policy brief. Additionally, the peer review component involves collaborative work where students 'give and receive peer feedback,' combining both independent and collaborative elements.

student_defined_projects.rationale: Students define their own research questions and topics for the Environmental Policy Research Project. The research proposal requires students to identify 'a relevant problem/issue for environmental politics' of their choosing, describe its importance, and outline their own research strategy, demonstrating significant student agency in shaping the project.

consequential_decision_making.rationale: Students make consequential intellectual decisions in selecting their research topic, determining what sources to include, and crafting policy recommendations in their policy brief for 'a policy-relevant audience.' These decisions have intellectual consequences for the quality and coherence of their analysis and recommendations.

extended_analytical_commitment.rationale: The multi-stage Environmental Policy Research Project requires extended analytical commitment with iterative review through multiple deliverables: research proposal, annotated bibliography, draft policy brief, peer feedback incorporation, and final policy brief. This structure necessitates sustained analysis and revision across the semester.

major_project.rationale: The Environmental Policy Research Project constitutes 30% of the course grade (research proposal 5%, annotated bibliography 5%, policy brief draft 5%, peer feedback 5%, final policy brief 10%), representing a substantial portion of assessment and requiring significant intellectual work culminating in an original policy brief.

portfolio_or_capstone.rationale: The Environmental Policy Research Project functions as a capstone-style artifact that integrates multiple components (research proposal, annotated bibliography, draft, peer review, final brief) across the term, demonstrating accumulated knowledge and skills in environmental policy analysis.

public_facing_outcome.rationale: The final policy brief explicitly addresses 'a policy-relevant audience' and is limited to 1200 words plus references, following the policy brief genre which is designed for public/professional audiences. This requires academic judgment in synthesizing research for non-academic stakeholders.

sustained_assessment.rationale: The course features sustained assessment through five quizzes (20%), two essay-based exams requiring ~750-word responses (50%), and the multi-component research project (30%). The majority of graded work requires critical analysis, with exams requiring essay responses and the research project demanding synthesis and original contribution.

lower_division_introductory.rationale: The course is numbered POL 223, which is a 200-level course, and is explicitly titled 'Introduction to Environmental Policy.' It is designed to 'provide an introduction to environmental politics and policy' and covers foundational concepts in the field, indicating it is a lower-division introductory course.

broad_introductory_coverage.rationale: The course description emphasizes breadth of coverage, stating it will 'explore important concepts, issues, problems, and questions' and 'critically examine a series of key problems and issues' including pollution, resource management, climate change, energy, and environmental justice. The structure of 'two halves, consisting of five main units' suggests survey-style breadth rather than depth in specialized topics.

skills_only_or_tool_training.rationale: The course is not focused on skills or tool training; it emphasizes critical thinking about environmental politics and policy, requiring analytical essays, research, and policy analysis rather than technical skill development.

lacks_major_deliverable.rationale: The course includes a major deliverable in the form of the Environmental Policy Research Project, culminating in a policy brief that constitutes 30% of the grade and involves multiple stages of development across the semester.

already_counted.rationale: There is no indication in the syllabus that this course is already counted through another Honors credit mechanism.

review_decision.rationale: While the course demonstrates interdisciplinarity and undergraduate research (meeting two pillars), satisfies all rigor criteria, all student agency criteria, and all demonstrable evidence of learning criteria, it triggers two critical exclusions: it is explicitly a lower-division introductory course (POL 223) and features broad introductory coverage designed to survey the field rather than provide advanced analysis. These exclusions disqualify the course from Honors approval despite its otherwise strong academic design.

course_information.course_title: Data Science and Public Policy: AI and Politics

interdisciplinary_academics.rationale: The course explicitly integrates knowledge from Social Sciences (political science, public policy) and Engineering/Technology (data science, AI, machine learning). The course description states it offers 'an interdisciplinary lens' to examine AI and big data's impact on governance, and learning outcomes require students to 'define and apply key concepts from data science and AI to assess their relevance for public policy design.' This demonstrates genuine integration across high-level domains.

undergraduate_research.rationale: Students engage in original inquiry through policy briefs that require formulating questions, analyzing evidence, and producing original findings. The learning outcomes specify students will 'develop, write, and deliver a policy brief that presents evidence-based, actionable recommendations for addressing a data- or AI-related policy challenge,' indicating knowledge creation beyond established answers.

community_and_global_engagement.rationale: The course connects to real-world contexts through examination of global issues (digital sovereignty, international AI governance) and includes ethical reflection. Topics include 'surveillance capitalism,' 'platform governance,' and case studies examining stakeholder perspectives. The course explores 'ethical, legal, and political implications' and includes 'stakeholder simulations' and analysis of 'competing interests and constraints in policy decision-making.'

leadership_development.rationale: The course develops leadership capacity through policy brief assignments requiring students to make consequential recommendations on AI governance issues. Students must 'develop, write, and deliver a policy brief that presents evidence-based, actionable recommendations' and engage in 'stakeholder simulations, policy design challenges, case-based debates, role-play exercises' that require decision-making and ethical analysis.

advanced_content.rationale: The course includes advanced theoretical and analytical content on AI ethics, algorithmic bias, policy design frameworks, and international governance structures. Topics include 'ethics of algorithmic decision-making,' 'platform governance,' 'surveillance capitalism,' and 'digital sovereignty,' requiring sophisticated understanding of both technical and political concepts.

sustained_inquiry.rationale: Students engage in sustained inquiry through multiple policy briefs developed across the term, with dedicated class time for 'developing research, writing, and communication strategies.' The course structure shows iterative development through preparation time, presentations, peer feedback, and final submissions.

independent_or_collaborative_work.rationale: The course requires significant independent work through policy briefs (20%) and research presentations (20%), plus collaborative work through group projects (20%) that include 'stakeholder simulations, policy design challenges, case-based debates, role-play exercises.' Peer feedback (10%) further demonstrates collaborative intellectual engagement.

student_defined_projects.rationale: Policy brief assignments allow students to select and shape their own policy questions within the AI and politics domain. The syllabus indicates students will write briefs 'on prompts related to the course' with significant latitude for individual focus and approach, requiring students to develop their own 'evidence-based, actionable recommendations.'

consequential_decision_making.rationale: Students make decisions with intellectual and ethical consequences through policy briefs that require actionable recommendations on real AI governance challenges. The course explicitly addresses 'ethical implications' and requires students to 'engage with diverse stakeholder perspectives to understand competing interests and constraints in policy decision-making.'

extended_analytical_commitment.rationale: Policy briefs require extended analytical commitment with iterative development shown through preparation periods, presentations, peer feedback roundtables, and final submissions. The peer feedback component (10%) and multiple presentation cycles demonstrate ongoing review and response throughout the term.

major_project.rationale: Two policy briefs (20% total) and two research presentations (20% total) constitute major projects representing 40% of the course grade. Each brief is 1-5 pages with citations and presentations, demonstrating substantial intellectual work.

portfolio_or_capstone.rationale: While the course includes multiple assignments, there is no explicit portfolio or capstone artifact that integrates work across the entire term.

public_facing_outcome.rationale: Research presentations are public-facing outcomes requiring students to 'clearly convey the core issue, stakeholders, and recommendations' to classroom audiences, with peer feedback indicating genuine public accountability for the quality of academic work.

sustained_assessment.rationale: The majority of graded work (70% - policy briefs, presentations, midterm exam, peer feedback) requires critical analysis, synthesis, or original contribution. The midterm (20%) emphasizes 'reasoning over memorization' with 'open-ended analytical questions,' and policy briefs require evidence-based recommendations.

lower_division_introductory.rationale: POL 228 is a 200-level course that appears to be a lower-division course introducing foundational concepts in data science and public policy. The course description explicitly states it 'provides foundational tools' and is 'open to students across all disciplines and years,' indicating an introductory level.

broad_introductory_coverage.rationale: While the course covers multiple topics, it focuses specifically on AI and politics with sustained analytical engagement rather than broad survey coverage. The four-module structure and policy brief requirements demonstrate depth over breadth.

skills_only_or_tool_training.rationale: The course is not skills-only training; it involves critical analysis of ethical, legal, and political implications of AI, not just technical skill development.

lacks_major_deliverable.rationale: The course includes multiple major deliverables: two policy briefs, two research presentations, and a midterm exam, all requiring substantial intellectual work.

already_counted.rationale: No evidence in the syllabus suggests this course is already counted through another Honors credit mechanism.

review_decision.rationale: While the course meets all four pillars and demonstrates strong rigor, student agency, and evidence of learning, it triggers the lower_division_introductory exclusion. POL 228 is a 200-level course explicitly described as providing 'foundational tools' and offering 'a critical introduction' that is 'open to students across all disciplines and years.' Despite its sophisticated content and assignments, its positioning as an introductory lower-division course makes it ineligible for Honors credit under the stated exclusion criteria.

interdisciplinary_academics.rationale: The course is squarely within the social sciences domain (Political Science), covering US foreign policy through historical and political science frameworks. While it mentions technology, world health, and space at the end, there is no evidence of integration with other high-level domains (Engineering, Natural Sciences, Humanities, Business) in terms of shared questions, combined methods, or joint theoretical frameworks.

undergraduate_research.rationale: Students write Issue Briefs and Policy Briefs analyzing historical foreign policy cases, but these are informative summaries and evaluations of established historical issues, not inquiry that extends beyond established answers or produces original findings. The assignments ask students to apply existing concepts to past cases rather than formulate new questions or generate new knowledge.

community_and_global_engagement.rationale: While the course addresses global issues and US foreign policy contexts, there is no evidence of sustained engagement with communities or organizations, nor structured reflection on ethical, social, or cultural dimensions of such engagement. The Statecraft simulation is a sandbox exercise among students, not engagement with real-world communities.

leadership_development.rationale: The Statecraft simulation assigns students leadership roles in fictional countries where they enact foreign policy, respond to world events, and make decisions with consequences within the simulation environment. Students practice decision-making, take responsibility for their country's actions, and reflect weekly on their choices, demonstrating intentional practice and reflection on leadership in a foreign policy context.

advanced_content.rationale: The course is explicitly introductory (POL 231: Introduction to US Foreign Policy) and designed to provide background and foundational concepts. The syllabus describes covering 'concepts, history, and case studies' and establishing 'a general vocabulary and theoretical framework,' which indicates foundational rather than advanced content.

sustained_inquiry.rationale: The course involves sustained analytical work across the term: two written foreign policy analyses (Issue Brief and Policy Brief) analyzing historical cases, a six-week Statecraft simulation requiring ongoing decision-making and weekly reflections, and continuous assessment through quizzes and exams. This represents sustained engagement with problem-solving and application of concepts throughout the semester.

independent_or_collaborative_work.rationale: Students complete significant independent work including two written foreign policy briefs (180 points total) and participate in a six-week collaborative Statecraft simulation (100 points) where they work with other students in leadership roles. The flexible milestone structure also requires substantial self-management and independent organization of work.

student_defined_projects.rationale: Students choose which historical foreign policy issues to analyze for their briefs and select their simulation schedule timing (early, middle, or late), but the assignments themselves are structured and prescribed. Students do not define their own research questions, project scope, or analytical approach beyond selecting from provided options.

consequential_decision_making.rationale: In the Statecraft simulation, students make foreign policy decisions as leaders of fictional countries, and these decisions have consequences within the simulation environment that affect their country's trajectory and interactions with other students' countries. Students must respond to the results of their choices and those of others over six weeks.

extended_analytical_commitment.rationale: Students engage in extended analytical work through two major policy briefs that require summarizing issues, identifying national interests, and evaluating policy options. The six-week Statecraft simulation with weekly reflections connecting to class concepts also represents extended analytical commitment with iterative engagement throughout the simulation period.

major_project.rationale: The course includes two written Foreign Policy Analysis assignments (Issue Brief worth 80 points and Policy Brief worth 100 points) totaling 180 points out of 1000, which together constitute 18% of the course grade. These briefs require analysis of historical foreign policy issues, identification of national interests, and evaluation of policy options.

portfolio_or_capstone.rationale: There is no portfolio or capstone-style artifact that integrates work across the term. The assignments are discrete pieces completed at different milestones without evidence of integration or synthesis across the semester's work.

public_facing_outcome.rationale: All course deliverables (briefs, simulation reflections, exams) are submitted to the instructor for grading. There is no indication that any work is shared publicly, presented to external audiences, or produces outcomes beyond the classroom.

sustained_assessment.rationale: While the course has continuous assessment (quizzes, concept matching, exams, briefs, simulation), the majority of graded work by points is quizzes (300 points), concept matching (100 points), and exams (300 points) totaling 700 of 1000 points. These primarily assess retention and comprehension rather than critical analysis or original contribution. Only the briefs (180 points, 18%) and simulation reflections (portion of 100 points) require sustained analytical work.

lower_division_introductory.rationale: The course is explicitly a lower-division introductory course (POL 231) designed to provide foundational background, theoretical tools, vocabulary, and concepts for understanding US foreign policy. The syllabus states it is 'designed to give you the background and theoretic tools you need to understand and evaluate US foreign policy' and covers foundational concepts.

broad_introductory_coverage.rationale: The course provides broad survey coverage of US foreign policy from the founding era through contemporary issues, covering multiple historical periods, regions (Middle East, Asia, Europe, Americas, Africa), and topics. The structure emphasizes breadth of historical coverage and establishment of general vocabulary rather than deep analysis of specific issues.

skills_only_or_tool_training.rationale: The course is not a skills-only or tool-training course. It covers substantive content about US foreign policy history, concepts, and analysis rather than focusing solely on skills development or technical training.

lacks_major_deliverable.rationale: The course includes major deliverables: two written Foreign Policy Analysis assignments (Issue Brief and Policy Brief) totaling 180 points and a six-week Statecraft simulation worth 100 points. These constitute significant intellectual work beyond routine assessments.

already_counted.rationale: There is no indication in the syllabus that this course is already counted through another Honors credit mechanism.

review_decision.rationale: The course meets one pillar (leadership_development through the Statecraft simulation), satisfies rigor requirements (sustained_inquiry and independent_or_collaborative_work), meets student agency criteria (consequential_decision_making and extended_analytical_commitment), and demonstrates learning through a major_project. However, the course triggers two critical exclusions: it is explicitly a lower_division_introductory course (POL 231) and follows a broad_introductory_coverage model surveying US foreign policy across centuries. These exclusions disqualify the course from Honors credit despite meeting other requirements.

course_information.course_title: International Relations Between Rich and Poor Nations

interdisciplinary_academics.rationale: The course explicitly integrates International Political Economy (IPE), combining perspectives from Social Sciences (political science) and Business and Economics (economic models, trade, finance). The syllabus states students will study 'ideas, theories, ideologies, norms, and economic models' and use these as 'analytical tools' to understand gaps between nations. The course content includes 'cost-benefit analysis, game theory' alongside political theories, demonstrating integration across high-level domains.

undergraduate_research.rationale: While the course involves application of IPE theories to analyze real-world issues and evaluation of policies, the syllabus does not describe students formulating original research questions, conducting investigations, or producing original findings that extend beyond established answers.

community_and_global_engagement.rationale: The course examines global issues theoretically and expects students to be 'conversant with major worldwide occurrences,' but there is no evidence of sustained engagement with communities, organizations, or structured reflection on ethical, social, or cultural dimensions of direct engagement.

leadership_development.rationale: The syllabus does not include intentional practice, reflection, or analysis of leadership or ethical frameworks, nor does it develop students' capacity to make decisions, take responsibility, or influence outcomes through structured leadership development activities.

advanced_content.rationale: The course includes advanced analytical content such as IPE theories (liberalism, mercantilism, structuralism), analytical tools including cost-benefit analysis and game theory, and evaluation of IMF and World Bank policy impacts. These represent advanced theoretical and methodological content appropriate for upper-division coursework.

sustained_inquiry.rationale: The course involves sustained inquiry across seven modules throughout the term, with students progressively applying IPE theories to analyze real-world issues and evaluating impact of global economic policies. The modular structure with learning exercises, exams, and optional bonus essays demonstrates sustained analytical work.

independent_or_collaborative_work.rationale: The asynchronous online format requires significant independent work as students progress through modules, complete readings, watch videos, and demonstrate understanding through exams. Students must self-manage their learning across the semester with flexible scheduling around cut-off dates.

student_defined_projects.rationale: While bonus essay opportunities are mentioned, the syllabus does not indicate that students define their own projects or questions. The core assessments are module exams with predetermined content and a final exam drawn from previous exams.

consequential_decision_making.rationale: Students make consequential decisions about their learning schedule within flexible parameters, deciding when to complete modules (within cut-off dates), whether to pursue bonus opportunities, and how to engage with optional 'original research' mentioned for extra credit assignments. These decisions have direct grade consequences.

extended_analytical_commitment.rationale: The course requires extended analytical commitment across seven modules throughout the semester, with students applying, evaluating, and understanding IPE concepts progressively. Module exams (90 minutes each) and optional bonus essays require sustained analytical work and synthesis of material over time.

major_project.rationale: While bonus essays are mentioned, they are optional and details are not provided. The primary assessments are module exams and a cumulative final exam, which do not constitute a major paper, project, design, or performance as a significant portion of the course grade.

portfolio_or_capstone.rationale: The syllabus does not describe a portfolio or capstone-style artifact integrating work across the term. The final exam is cumulative but draws from previous exams rather than integrating new synthesis.

public_facing_outcome.rationale: There is no evidence of public-facing or applied outcomes requiring academic judgment. Assessments appear to be internal to the course (exams and optional essays).

sustained_assessment.rationale: The graded work includes seven module exams (90% of grade) requiring application, evaluation, and understanding of IPE concepts, plus a comprehensive final exam (10%). The sustained assessment structure with exams including 'brief text entry questions' alongside multiple choice suggests a majority of graded work requires analysis and synthesis.

lower_division_introductory.rationale: The syllabus explicitly states 'This course is an introductory survey to the field of International Political Economy (IPE)' and the course number (23500) indicates a 200-level course, which is lower-division and designed to introduce foundational concepts.

broad_introductory_coverage.rationale: As stated, this is 'an introductory survey' covering IPE theories, frameworks, case studies, and analytical tools. The breadth of topics (trade, finance, development, debt, environment, IMF, World Bank) suggests coverage-oriented rather than advanced analysis focus typical of introductory courses.

skills_only_or_tool_training.rationale: While analytical tools are taught, the course goes beyond skills-only training by requiring application of theories to real-world issues and evaluation of policy impacts, demonstrating substantive content beyond tool training.

lacks_major_deliverable.rationale: The course includes sustained assessment through seven module exams and a final exam, along with optional bonus essays. While not a single major project, the sustained assessment structure constitutes significant intellectual deliverables.

already_counted.rationale: There is no indication in the syllabus that this course is already counted through another Honors credit mechanism.

review_decision.rationale: Despite meeting one pillar (interdisciplinary_academics) and satisfying rigor, student agency, and demonstrable evidence requirements, the course triggers two critical exclusions: it is explicitly described as 'an introductory survey to the field of International Political Economy' and is a 200-level lower-division course designed to introduce foundational concepts with broad coverage. These exclusions disqualify the course from Honors credit approval.

interdisciplinary_academics.rationale: The course demonstrates cross-domain interdisciplinarity by integrating knowledge from Social Sciences (international relations, political science) with Engineering and Technology (military technology, weapons systems) and History (Humanities). The course examines how technological changes in weapons systems interact with social and political consequences, addressing questions that cannot be answered from a single domain perspective. For example, the syllabus explores 'the immediate impact on the conduct and nature of war as well as the broader social and political implications of military change,' demonstrating integration of engineering/technology analysis with political and historical frameworks.

undergraduate_research.rationale: The syllabus does not provide evidence of students engaging in inquiry, investigation, or knowledge creation that extends beyond established answers. The course focuses on learning about historical military revolutions and current debates, with assessment through exams that test comprehension of material rather than original research or investigation.

community_and_global_engagement.rationale: While the course addresses global issues related to warfare and international relations, there is no evidence of sustained engagement with communities or organizations, nor structured reflection on ethical, social, or cultural dimensions through direct engagement. The course is lecture-based with readings and exams.

leadership_development.rationale: The syllabus does not include evidence of developing students' capacity to make decisions, take responsibility, or influence outcomes through intentional practice, reflection, and analysis of leadership frameworks. The course focuses on analytical understanding of military technology and international relations rather than leadership development.

advanced_content.rationale: The course includes advanced theoretical and analytical content, as evidenced by learning objectives such as 'Explain the elements and requirements of nuclear deterrence (and debates about the requirements)' and the examination of complex topics like the Revolution in Military Affairs, strategic bombing theory, and nuclear strategy. The course analyzes sophisticated debates about the role of technology in warfare at a level beyond introductory treatment.

sustained_inquiry.rationale: The course involves sustained inquiry across the term through examination of multiple military revolutions from historical (gunpowder revolution 1400s-1500s, industrial revolution) to contemporary (RMA) perspectives. Students trace the evolution of military technology and its social/political implications throughout the semester, addressing complex questions like 'what does the American experience in Iraq since 2003 indicate about the role of technology in changing the character of warfare?'

independent_or_collaborative_work.rationale: The syllabus does not provide evidence of significant independent or collaborative intellectual work. Assessment consists solely of three non-cumulative exams with short answers and essays, without mention of projects, papers, or collaborative assignments that would require sustained independent work.

student_defined_projects.rationale: The syllabus does not mention student-defined or student-shaped projects or questions. All topics and questions are predetermined by the instructor.

consequential_decision_making.rationale: There is no evidence in the syllabus of decision-making with intellectual or ethical consequences. Students respond to exam questions on predetermined topics but do not make consequential decisions about their work.

extended_analytical_commitment.rationale: While exams include essays requiring analysis, there is no evidence of extended analytical commitment requiring iterative review and response. The three non-cumulative exams are discrete assessment events without revision or extended development.

major_project.rationale: The course does not include a major paper, project, design, or performance. Assessment consists solely of three exams (weighted 20%, 40%, and 40%).

portfolio_or_capstone.rationale: There is no portfolio or capstone-style artifact mentioned in the syllabus.

public_facing_outcome.rationale: The course does not include a public-facing or applied outcome. Assessment is entirely through traditional exams.

sustained_assessment.rationale: The course has a sustained assessment structure through three non-cumulative exams that together constitute 100% of the grade. Each exam includes 'short answers of varying formats and an essay,' requiring critical analysis of complex topics such as nuclear deterrence theory, military revolutions, and the Revolution in Military Affairs. The exam essays require synthesis and analysis of course material across multiple learning objectives.

lower_division_introductory.rationale: This is a 200-level course (POL 237), but it is not designed as a foundational introduction. Rather, it examines specialized topics in military technology and international relations with advanced analytical content.

broad_introductory_coverage.rationale: While the course covers multiple historical periods, it is not a broad introductory survey. It focuses specifically on the relationship between weapons technology and international relations, with sustained analysis of military revolutions rather than general coverage.

skills_only_or_tool_training.rationale: The course is not skills-only or tool-training focused. It emphasizes analytical understanding of complex political and technological phenomena.

lacks_major_deliverable.rationale: The course includes three substantial exams with essays that serve as major deliverables requiring critical analysis and synthesis.

already_counted.rationale: There is no evidence in the syllabus that this course is already counted through another Honors credit mechanism.

review_decision.rationale: While the course meets the interdisciplinary academics pillar through integration of political science, history, and military technology, and satisfies rigor requirements (advanced content, sustained inquiry) and demonstrable evidence of learning (sustained assessment), it does not meet the student agency and responsibility requirement. The course lacks student-defined projects, consequential decision-making, or extended analytical commitment with iterative review. All work is predetermined by the instructor and assessed through traditional exams without opportunities for student agency in shaping their intellectual work. At least one student agency criterion must be satisfied for Honors approval.

interdisciplinary_academics.rationale: The course is cross-listed as POL 326/AAS 371, integrating Political Science with African American Studies. The syllabus demonstrates integration through examination of Black political participation using both political science frameworks (electoral politics, participation theory) and African American Studies perspectives (Black liberation, racial experience), with readings that combine social science methods with historical and cultural analysis.

undergraduate_research.rationale: The course requires an 8-10 page term paper where students must apply theoretical insights from course texts to current political events, requiring original analysis and application. Students also lead critical analysis discussions applying key insights to current or historical political events, demonstrating inquiry and knowledge creation.

community_and_global_engagement.rationale: While the course addresses real-world political issues and current events, there is no evidence of sustained engagement with communities or organizations, nor structured reflection on ethical, social, or cultural dimensions of external engagement.

leadership_development.rationale: The syllabus does not include evidence of intentional leadership development activities, decision-making practice in leadership contexts, or analysis of leadership frameworks, though students do lead discussions.

advanced_content.rationale: The course includes advanced theoretical content on political participation, with readings from university press publications examining complex topics like Black nationalism, civic activism, and political behavior. The learning outcomes require students to analyze political and legal frameworks and connect them to contemporary events.

sustained_inquiry.rationale: Students engage in sustained inquiry through the term paper (8-10 pages) examining a topic from course texts applied to current politics, and through ongoing quizzes and short assignments (at least 12 throughout the semester) that require continuous analytical engagement.

independent_or_collaborative_work.rationale: The course requires significant independent work through the 8-10 page term paper (25% of grade) and collaborative work through student-led group discussions (3-5 students, 10% of grade) analyzing course texts and applying insights to political events.

student_defined_projects.rationale: The term paper allows students to select which course text to examine and which current political event to analyze, giving students significant agency in defining their project focus within the course framework.

consequential_decision_making.rationale: Students make consequential intellectual decisions in their term papers by selecting which theoretical frameworks to apply and how to connect them to current events. The student-led discussions require groups to make decisions about how to present and apply course material.

extended_analytical_commitment.rationale: The 8-10 page term paper requires extended analytical commitment throughout the semester, with feedback provided up to two weeks after submission. The comprehensive final exam also requires students to synthesize and apply material from across the entire course.

major_project.rationale: The 8-10 page term paper constitutes a major project accounting for 25% of the final grade, requiring students to demonstrate understanding and application of course texts to current political events.

portfolio_or_capstone.rationale: The syllabus does not describe a portfolio or capstone-style artifact that integrates work across the term.

public_facing_outcome.rationale: While students lead class discussions, there is no evidence of public-facing outcomes beyond the classroom or applied outcomes requiring academic judgment in external contexts.

sustained_assessment.rationale: The course has sustained assessment throughout the semester including at least 12 quizzes/short assignments (15%), student-led discussions (10%), a term paper (25%), and two exams (50%), with the majority requiring critical analysis and application of course concepts.

lower_division_introductory.rationale: This is a 300-level course (POL 326/AAS 371), which is upper-division, not lower-division. The course has no prerequisites and builds advanced analytical skills.

broad_introductory_coverage.rationale: While the course has no prerequisites, it focuses on advanced analysis of Black political participation rather than broad introductory coverage. The course requires application of theoretical frameworks to current events and sustained analytical work.

skills_only_or_tool_training.rationale: The course is focused on understanding political participation and Black politics through theoretical frameworks and analysis, not skills-only or tool training.

lacks_major_deliverable.rationale: The course includes a major deliverable: an 8-10 page term paper worth 25% of the final grade that requires original analysis and application.

already_counted.rationale: There is no indication in the syllabus that this course is already counted through another Honors credit mechanism.

review_decision.rationale: The course meets the interdisciplinary academics pillar through its integration of Political Science and African American Studies, and the undergraduate research pillar through the term paper and critical analysis assignments. It satisfies all rigor criteria (advanced content, sustained inquiry, and independent/collaborative work), all student agency criteria (student-defined projects, consequential decision-making, and extended analytical commitment), and multiple demonstrable evidence criteria (major project and sustained assessment). No exclusions apply.

interdisciplinary_academics.rationale: The course integrates Political Science/International Relations (Social Sciences) with Environmental Studies (Natural Sciences) and Environmental Political Theory (Humanities). The course description explicitly states it provides 'a critical overview of global environmental politics from the perspective of political science, international relations, and environmental political theory,' examining ecological crises through theories of collective action, capitalism, governance, and political economy.
